 002: Basic Python Lebwohl-Lasher code.  Based on the paper
 003: P.A. Lebwohl and G. Lasher, Phys. Rev. A, 6, 426-429 (1972).
 004: This version in 2D.
 005: 
 006: Run at the command line by typing:
 007: 
 008: python LebwohlLasher.py <ITERATIONS> <SIZE> <TEMPERATURE> <PLOTFLAG>
 009: 
 010: where:
 011:   ITERATIONS = number of Monte Carlo steps, where 1MCS is when each cell
 012:       has attempted a change once on average (i.e. SIZE*SIZE attempts)
 013:   SIZE = side length of square lattice
 014:   TEMPERATURE = reduced temperature in range 0.0 - 2.0.
 015:   PLOTFLAG = 0 for no plot, 1 for energy plot and 2 for angle plot.
 016: 
 017: The initial configuration is set at random. The boundaries
 018: are periodic throughout the simulation.  During the
 019: time-stepping, an array containing two domains is used; these
 020: domains alternate between old data and new data.
 021: 
 022: SH 16-Oct-23
 023: """
 024:

 219:     """
 220:     Arguments:
 221: 	  arr (float(nmax,nmax)) = array that contains lattice data;

 223:       nmax (int) = side length of square lattice.
 224:     Description:
